docs.lead_paragraph: Attorneys general have become the object of pursuit by lobbyists who use campaign contributions, personal appeals and other means to sway investigations or negotiate favorable deals, an investigation by The New York Times has found.

headline.main: Lobbyists, Bearing Gifts, Pursue Attorneys General
headline.print_headline: Lobbyists, Bearing Gifts, Pursue Attorneys General

docs.abstract: Attorneys general across nation are being aggressively pursued by lobbyists who use campaign contributions, personal appeals at lavish conferences and other means to push them to drop investigations, negotiate favorable settlements or pressure federal regulators; robust industry of lobbyists and lawyers has blossomed as attorneys general join to conduct multistate investigations and push into areas as diverse as securities fraud and Internet crimes.
docs.snippet: Attorneys general have become the object of pursuit by lobbyists who use campaign contributions, personal appeals and other means to sway investigations or negotiate favorable deals, an investigation by The New York Times has found.

byline.contributor: Stacey Solie contributed reporting from Seattle. Griff Palmer and Kitty Bennett contributed research.

docs.lead_paragraph: The way wine is used as a character device for women on TV tells us a lot about how it is viewed in popular culture.

headline.main: Red Wine Is the Drink of Choice on ‘Scandal’ and ‘The Good Wife’
headline.print_headline: On TV, Powerful Women Gulp Reds

docs.abstract: Eric Asimov The Pour column observes that red wine is increasingly being used as prop for powerful female characters on television; says that television portrayal of wine, in which it is consumed in large quantities and used to help characters endure life's travails, is anathema to connoisseurs who prefer to savor beverage.
docs.snippet: The way wine is used as a character device for women on TV tells us a lot about how it is viewed in popular culture.
